content:
If Akira was adopted by Kaguya, his life story leading up to this point could be quite different. Perhaps he was orphaned at a young age and left to fend for himself in the harsh desert environment of the Land of the Red Storms. Despite the odds against him, he managed to survive through a combination of cunning, resourcefulness, and sheer determination.

One day, Kaguya and her entourage were passing through the desert on a diplomatic mission when they stumbled upon Akira. He was just a boy at the time, but he had already developed a reputation as a skilled hunter and survivalist. Kaguya was impressed by his tenacity and resourcefulness, and took him under her wing. She saw potential in him and decided to adopt him as her younger brother, bringing him back to her own country to be raised alongside her two biological sons.

Initially, Akira struggled to adjust to life in Kaguya's country, which was vastly different from the harsh and unforgiving desert environment he was used to. However, with Kaguya's guidance and support, he eventually found his place and became an integral part of her court. His skills as a hunter and tracker proved invaluable on several diplomatic and military missions, and he quickly became known as one of Kaguya's most trusted advisors and confidants.

Despite his adoption, Akira never forgot his roots or his past. He remained deeply connected to the Land of the Red Storms, and often returned there to hunt and explore. However, he was always grateful to Kaguya for taking him in and giving him a second chance at life.
